Introduction

  • Chapter 5 is a central chapter.
  • It covers how to manipulate a dataframe/tibble.
  • I highly recommend that you work through (follow) the example in the book.
  • Suggestions:

    • Do it in a Quarto Document.

    • Copy the code from the book into your own Quarto Document.

    • Try to experiment with the code and write your own remarks/comment about the code and how it works.

  • I will cover the most important material in lectures, but we do not have time to cover all the finer details.

Small collection of verbs

  • We will use a small collection of verbs:

    • filter(): show us just the data that satisfies one or more conditions

    • arrange(): sort (rearranges) the rows

    • select(): select some of the variables (remove the variables that does not interest us)

    • mutate(): make new variables in the dataframe/tibble

      • transmute() only keeps the new variables

      • rename(): change the name of a variable (this is really a variant of mutate()).

  • summarise() and group_by(): Group by one or more criteria and then summarise the variables (max, min, mean, median, sd etc.)
  • The functions above are from the dplyr package which is part of the tidyverse.

Data: nycflights13

  • We will follow the book and use the dataset nycflights13.
  • The dataset is in a package (called nycflights13) that we have to install first.
  • See also:

    • vignette("dplyr"),

    • starwars dataset,

    • vignette("grouping"),

    • vignette("colwise") and

    • vignette("rowwise")

The pipe, 5.6.1 and more details in chap. 18

  • Three equivalent ways to calculate in R
  • Function in function in function in function â€¦
  • Temporary variables

Function in function in function â€¦

Code 
set.seed(1234)
res_mean_rnorm_3dig <- paste("Result:", round(mean(rnorm(n = 10, mean = 0, sd = 1)), digits = 3), sep = "")
res_mean_rnorm_3dig
[1] "Result:-0.383"

Temporary variables

  • Meaningful names with clean-up
Code 
set.seed(1234)
res_rnorm <- rnorm(n = 10, mean = 0, sd = 1)
res_mean_rnorm <- mean(res_rnorm)
res_mean_rnorm_3dig <- round(res_mean_rnorm, digits = 3)
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string <- paste("Result:", res_mean_rnorm_3dig, sep = "")
# print result
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string
[1] "Result:-0.383"
Code 
# cleanup
rm(res_rnorm, res_mean_rnorm, res_mean_rnorm_3dig, res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string)

Temporary variables (in reality)

  • What we usually do, bad variable names and no clean-up
Code 
set.seed(1234)
tmp <- rnorm(n = 10, mean = 0, sd = 1)
tmp1 <- mean(tmp)
tmp2 <- round(tmp1, digits = 3)
paste("Result:", tmp2, sep = "")
[1] "Result:-0.383"
Code 
# ^t, object names that start with 't' 
ls(pattern = "^t")
[1] "tmp"  "tmp1" "tmp2"

The pipe with addin viewpipesteps

Code 
set.seed(1234)
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string <- 
  rnorm(n = 10, mean = 0, sd = 1) %>%
  mean() %>%
  round(digits = 3) %>% 
  # The dot '.' is to show where the content of the pipe should be put
  paste("Result:", .)
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string
[1] "Result: -0.383"

The pipe cont.

  • What would happen if we dropped the â€˜.â€™ in paste("Result:", .)?
Code 
set.seed(1234)
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string <- 
  rnorm(n = 10, mean = 0, sd = 1) %>%
  mean() %>%
  round(digits = 3) %>% 
  # The dot '.' is to show where the content of the pipe should be put
  paste("Result:")
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string
[1] "-0.383 Result:"

The pipe with Addin viewpipesteps

  • Run the set.seed() function
  • Select the pipe
  • Choose Print Pipe Chain Steps

The pipe with Addin viewpipesteps cont.

  • Select Print Pipe Chain Steps from Addins menu

The pipe with Addin viewpipesteps cont.

  • In the Console we will get the result (output) of every step in the pipe

The pipe, alternative not much used

Code 
set.seed(1234)
rnorm(
  n = 10,
  mean = 0,
  sd = 1
) %>%
  mean() %>%
  round(digits = 3) %>% 
  paste("Result:", .) -> res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string
res_mean_rnorm_3dig_string
[1] "Result: -0.383"

More about the pipe

  • Work like the unix shell pipe (â€˜|â€™)
  • Output from one function is the input of the next function
  • Temporary variables in the background, but we donâ€™t have to come up with names or remove them when not needed any more.
  • Uses the fact that most R functions have the data as their first argument
    • The regression function lm(formula, data, â€¦) is an important counter example
    • We use â€˜.â€™ to specify where the data in the pipe enters a function
      • If not the first argument (function_name(., other arguments) is the default)
  • The tidyverse is designed to work well with the pipe
    • The sf packages we will encounter next year are also designed to work well with tidyverse and pipes

nycflights13

Code 
# see setup at the top for loading of 
# nycflights13 package
?nycflights13
No documentation for 'nycflights13' in specified packages and libraries:
you could try '??nycflights13'

Load the nycflights13 package.

  • Get help via Packages pane and click nycflights13.

nycflights13

  • The package contains 5 datsets

    • airline

    • airports

    • flights

    • planes

    • weather

  • use ? to read the help for each
Code 
?flights

Variables in flights (from help)

  • year, month, day: Date of departure.
  • dep_time, arr_time: Actual departure and arrival times (format HHMM or HMM), local tz.
  • sched_dep_time, sched_arr_time: Scheduled departure and arrival times (format HHMM or HMM), local tz.
  • dep_delay, arr_delay: Departure and arrival delays, in minutes. Negative times represent early departures/arrivals.
  • carrier: Two letters carrier abbreviation. See airlines to get name.
  • flight: Flight number.

Variables in flights (from help) cont.

  • tailnum: Plane tail number. See planes for additional metadata.
  • origin, dest: Origin and destination. See airports for additional metadata.
  • air_time: Amount of time spent in the air, in minutes.
  • distance: Distance between airports, in miles.
  • hour, minute: Time of scheduled departure broken into hour and minutes.
  • time_hour: Scheduled date and hour of the flight as a POSIXct date. Along with origin, can be used to join flights data to weather data.

Code 
# what size is it
dim(flights)

Code 
# what type; data.frame, tibble?

  filter(month == 1, day %in% c(1, 15, 30)) %>%

Operators

  • == NB! not =; equal
  • <, >, >=, <=
  • ! for negate, !near(1/5 * 5, 5/5) is FALSE
  • | is or, ex. TRUE | FALSE is TRUE
  • & is and, ex. TRUE & FALSE is FALSE. TRUE & TRUE is TRUE, !(TRUE & FALSE) is TRUE
  • %in% is very handy, x %in% c(1, 3), TRUE if x is 1 or 3

Use near() not == for double/numeric

Code 
(1/49) * 49 == 1
[1] FALSE
Code 
# and
(1/49) * 49 == 49/49
[1] FALSE
Code 
# but
(1/5) * 5 == 5/5
[1] TRUE
Code 
# but
(5/4) == 1.25
[1] TRUE

Use near() not == for double/numeric cont.

  • use near()
Code 
near(1/49 * 49, 1)
[1] TRUE
Code 
near(1/5 * 5, 5/5)
[1] TRUE

Small Exercise

1) How many flights were there in April and September (total)?

2) How many flights were there in total the first two days of a month?

3) How may flights were there during 2013 that had an arrival delay greater than or equal to 15 min., but less than 30 min.?

Solution Small Exercise

1) How many flights were there in April and September (total)?

Solution Small Exercise cont.

2) How many flights were there in total the first two days of a month?

Solution Small Exercise cont.

3) How may flights were there during 2013 that had an arrival delay greater than or equal to 15 min., but less than 30 min.?

  • Note use of .. Needed when using classic functions like [.

Missing values NA

  • General rule: If one is NA, whole result will be NA,

    • ex. sum(c(1, 2, NA, 4, 5)) will return

    • NA.

  • Check for NA with is.na()
    • NOT x == NA
  • is.na() returns TRUE if NA
  • How to count number of NAs in a vector?

    • sum(is.na(flights$arr_delay)) will return

    • 9430

  • How to select the same variables, but only for May?

filter() and select() in pipe

Code 
# Use a pipe
my_vars_May <- flights %>%
  filter(month == 5) %>%
  select(day, month, year, arr_delay)
head(my_vars_May)
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 4
    day month  year arr_delay
  <int> <int> <int>     <dbl>
1     1     5  2013       408
2     1     5  2013         1
3     1     5  2013        -4
4     1     5  2013        -9
5     1     5  2013       -23
6     1     5  2013        -6
  • How do we find median arr_delay in May?

filter() and select() in pipe cont.

Code 
# Use a pipe
my_vars_May <-  flights %>%
  filter(month == 5) %>%
  # renaming of variable in select() function
  select(arrival_delay = arr_delay)

median(my_vars_May$arrival_delay, na.rm = TRUE)
[1] -8
  • Note renaming of variable in select statement
  • To calculate the median direct in the pipe we need another function called summarise() that we will cover soon.

New variable, use mutate

Code 
my_new_data <- flights %>%
  select(year:day, ends_with("delay"), distance, air_time) %>%
  mutate(
    gain = dep_delay - arr_delay,
    speed = (distance/air_time) * 60
    ) %>%
  select(year:day, gain, everything()) %>%
  arrange(gain)
head(my_new_data, n = 5) 
# A tibble: 5 Ã— 9
   year month   day  gain dep_delay arr_delay distance air_time speed
  <int> <int> <int> <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl>
1  2013    11     1  -196        -2       194     2475      336  442.
2  2013     4    18  -181        -2       179     1389      234  356.
3  2013     8     8  -165       180       345     2565      420  366.
4  2013     7    10  -161        16       177     2586      387  401.
5  2013     6    27  -157        43       200      544      120  272
  • Note use of the helper function ends_with()

    • Many helper functions and they can save a lot of time

    • See ?select for details

  • How do we get speed between dep_delay and arr_delay?

New variable, use mutate cont.

Code 
my_new_data <- flights %>%
  select(year:day, ends_with("delay"), distance, air_time) %>%
  mutate(
    gain = dep_delay - arr_delay,
    speed = (distance/air_time) * 60
    ) %>%
  select(year:day, gain, dep_delay, speed, everything()) %>%
  arrange(gain)
head(my_new_data, n=5) 
# A tibble: 5 Ã— 9
   year month   day  gain dep_delay speed arr_delay distance air_time
  <int> <int> <int> <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1  2013    11     1  -196        -2  442.       194     2475      336
2  2013     4    18  -181        -2  356.       179     1389      234
3  2013     8     8  -165       180  366.       345     2565      420
4  2013     7    10  -161        16  401.       177     2586      387
5  2013     6    27  -157        43  272        200      544      120

transmute()

  • When should we use transmute()
  • When we just want to keep the new variable(s)

transmute()

Code 
my_data <- flights %>%
    transmute(
    gain = dep_delay - arr_delay,
    speed = (distance/air_time) * 60
    ) %>%
  arrange(gain)
head(my_data, n = 3)
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
   gain speed
  <dbl> <dbl>
1  -196  442.
2  -181  356.
3  -165  366.

transmute() alternative to mutate() and then select()

Code 
my_data <- flights %>%
    mutate(
    gain = dep_delay - arr_delay,
    speed = (distance/air_time) * 60
    ) %>%
  select(gain, speed) %>%
  arrange(gain)
head(my_data, n = 3)
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
   gain speed
  <dbl> <dbl>
1  -196  442.
2  -181  356.
3  -165  366.

summarise() and group_by()

Code 
# note na.rm = TRUE, else everything will be NA 
# even if just one NA
flights %>%
  summarise(delay = median(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  delay
  <dbl>
1    -5
  • Our example with arr_delay from earlier
Code 
flights %>%
  filter(month == 5) %>%
  select(arr_delay) %>%
  summarise(median_arr_delay = median(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 1 Ã— 1
  median_arr_delay
             <dbl>
1               -8

summarise() and group_by()

  • How to get median arr_delay for each month?
Code 
flights %>%
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(median_arr_delay = median(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 12 Ã— 2
   month median_arr_delay
   <int>            <dbl>
 1     1               -3
 2     2               -3
 3     3               -6
 4     4               -2
 5     5               -8
 6     6               -2
 7     7               -2
 8     8               -5
 9     9              -12
10    10               -7
11    11               -6
12    12                2
Code 
#siste

MSB105
